content_text: Python is a high-level, interpreted programming language known for its simplicity and readability. It was created by Guido van Rossum and first released in 1991. Python supports multiple programming paradigms including procedural, object-oriented, and functional programming. Key features include dynamic typing, automatic memory management, and a comprehensive standard library.
content_summary: Introduction to Python programming language fundamentals
subject: Computer Science

content_text: Variables in Python are containers for storing data values. Unlike other programming languages, Python has no command for declaring a variable. A variable is created the moment you first assign a value to it. Python supports various data types including integers (int), floating-point numbers (float), strings (str), lists, tuples, dictionaries, and sets. Variables can change type after they have been set.
content_summary: Understanding variables and data types in Python
subject: Computer Science

content_text: A function is a block of code which only runs when it is called. Functions can receive data, known as parameters, and can return data as a result. In Python, a function is defined using the def keyword, followed by the function name and parentheses containing any parameters. Functions help break programs into smaller, modular chunks and promote code reusability.
content_summary: How to define and use functions in Python
subject: Computer Science

content_text: Machine Learning is a subset of artificial intelligence that enables systems to learn and improve from experience without being explicitly programmed. The three main types of machine learning are: Supervised Learning (learning from labeled data), Unsupervised Learning (finding patterns in unlabeled data), and Reinforcement Learning (learning through trial and error with rewards). Machine learning algorithms build mathematical models based on sample data, known as training data, to make predictions or decisions.
content_summary: Overview of machine learning concepts and types
subject: Computer Science

content_text: Data structures are ways of organizing and storing data so that it can be accessed and modified efficiently. Common data structures include arrays, linked lists, stacks, queues, trees, and graphs. Each data structure has its own advantages and is suited for specific types of operations. Understanding data structures is fundamental to writing efficient algorithms and solving complex programming problems.
content_summary: Overview of fundamental data structures in computer science
subject: Computer Science

content_text: An array is a collection of elements stored at contiguous memory locations. Arrays allow random access to elements using an index. The time complexity for accessing elements is O(1), while insertion and deletion at arbitrary positions is O(n). Arrays are the foundation for many other data structures. In most programming languages, arrays have a fixed size, though dynamic arrays (like Python lists) can grow.
subject: Computer Science

content_text: A Binary Search Tree (BST) is a binary tree where for each node, all elements in the left subtree are less than the node, and all elements in the right subtree are greater. BSTs support efficient searching, insertion, and deletion with average time complexity O(log n). In the worst case (when the tree becomes unbalanced), operations degrade to O(n). Self-balancing BSTs like AVL and Red-Black trees maintain O(log n) performance.
content_summary: Binary Search Trees and their properties
subject: Computer Science

content_text: Sorting algorithms arrange elements in a specific order. Common algorithms include Bubble Sort (O(n²)), Selection Sort (O(n²)), Insertion Sort (O(n²)), Merge Sort (O(n log n)), Quick Sort (O(n log n) average, O(n²) worst), and Heap Sort (O(n log n)). The choice of algorithm depends on the data size, distribution, and memory constraints. Stable sorts preserve the relative order of equal elements.
content_summary: Overview of sorting algorithms and their complexities
subject: Computer Science

content_text: A Database Management System (DBMS) is software that enables users to create, maintain, and control access to databases. Key features include data independence, efficient data access, data integrity, concurrent access, and recovery from failures. DBMS types include relational (SQL), document (NoSQL), key-value, graph, and time-series databases. The relational model organizes data into tables with rows and columns.
subject: Computer Science

content_text: Normalization is the process of organizing data to reduce redundancy and improve data integrity. The main normal forms are: 1NF (eliminates repeating groups), 2NF (eliminates partial dependencies), 3NF (eliminates transitive dependencies), BCNF (stronger than 3NF), and 4NF/5NF (handle multi-valued and join dependencies). Higher normalization reduces redundancy but may impact query performance, leading to denormalization in some scenarios.
content_summary: Database normalization concepts and normal forms
subject: Computer Science

content_text: The OSI (Open Systems Interconnection) model defines seven layers for network communication: Physical (bits transmission), Data Link (frames, MAC), Network (packets, IP, routing), Transport (segments, TCP/UDP), Session (connection management), Presentation (data formatting), and Application (user interfaces). Each layer provides services to the layer above and uses services from the layer below.
subject: Computer Science

content_text: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) is a connection-oriented protocol that provides reliable data transmission. It uses a three-way handshake for connection establishment (SYN, SYN-ACK, ACK), sequence numbers for ordering, acknowledgments for reliability, and flow control with sliding window. TCP ensures data arrives complete, in order, and without errors. It operates at the Transport layer of the OSI model.
content_summary: TCP protocol and reliable data transmission
subject: Computer Science

content_text: A process is an instance of a program in execution. Each process has its own memory space (code, data, stack, heap) and process control block (PCB) containing process state, program counter, registers, and scheduling information. Process states include new, ready, running, waiting, and terminated. The operating system manages process creation, scheduling, synchronization, and termination.
subject: Computer Science

content_text: CPU scheduling determines which process runs on the CPU. Algorithms include: First-Come-First-Served (FCFS) - simple but may cause convoy effect, Shortest Job First (SJF) - optimal average waiting time but may cause starvation, Round Robin - fair time-sharing with time quantum, Priority Scheduling - can cause starvation, solved by aging. Metrics include turnaround time, waiting time, response time, and throughput.
content_summary: CPU scheduling algorithms and their characteristics
subject: Computer Science

content_text: Object-Oriented Programming (OOP) is a programming paradigm based on objects containing data (attributes) and code (methods). The four pillars of OOP are: Encapsulation (bundling data and methods, hiding internal details), Abstraction (showing only essential features), Inheritance (deriving new classes from existing ones), and Polymorphism (same interface for different implementations). OOP promotes code reusability, modularity, and easier maintenance.
subject: Computer Science

content_text: Inheritance is a mechanism where a new class (derived/child class) inherits properties and behaviors from an existing class (base/parent class). Types include single inheritance (one parent), multiple inheritance (multiple parents), multilevel inheritance (chain of inheritance), and hierarchical inheritance (multiple children from one parent). Inheritance promotes code reuse and establishes an 'is-a' relationship between classes.
subject: Computer Science

content_text: In calculus, a limit is the value that a function approaches as the input approaches some value. Limits are essential to calculus and are used to define continuity, derivatives, and integrals. The formal definition uses epsilon-delta notation. Understanding limits helps us analyze function behavior near specific points and at infinity.
subject: Mathematics

content_text: Newton's three laws of motion form the foundation of classical mechanics. The First Law (Law of Inertia) states that an object remains at rest or in uniform motion unless acted upon by an external force. The Second Law states that Force equals mass times acceleration (F=ma). The Third Law states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. These laws explain how objects move and interact.
content_summary: Explanation of Newton's three laws of motion
subject: Physics
